page.title: 14Breamore's Past 1
page.content: Breamore,the name deriving from "Brumore" meaning"a moor or marsh covered with broom",was settled in pre-historic times,as evidenced by the several long and round barrows(ancient burial sites)found here. The Doomsday survey of 1086 suggests that Breamore was a royal manor, supplying accomodation for the king and his attendants. The village then was small,with twelve dwellings along what is now Upper Street. Breamore church,erected about 1000 AD,may have been financed by{Ethelred 2. } In the Medieval period,the Manor house was on the site of Home farm.Wheat, barley,oats,and peas were grown on the large open village fields,named Northfield,Southfield and Churchfield. In the 12th c.,the{Priory of St. {Michael}was founded. The{Austin Canons were largely self-sufficent,producing
